page.title: 2005 Texas vs. Texas A&M football game

revisions.rev:
<!-- Note: The rankings in the Infobox NCAA football single game are the rankings coming INTO this specific game. --> <!-- Note: The records (E.g. 1-0 in the Infobox NCAA football single game are the records coming INTO this specific game. --> {{Infobox NCAA football single game |Name=[[Lone Star Showdown]] - (112th meeting) |date=November 25, 2005 |Year=2005 |Visitor School=University of Texas at Austin |Visitor Name Short=Texas |Visitor Nickname=Longhorns |Visitor Record=10-0 |Visitor AP=2 |Visitor Coaches=2 |Visitor BCS= |Visitor Coach=[[Mack Brown]] |Visitor1=14 |Visitor2=7 |Visitor3=13 |Visitor4=6 |Visitor Total=40 |Home School=Texas A&M University |Home Name Short=Texas A&M |Home Nickname=Aggies |Home Record=5-5 |Home AP= |Home Coaches= |Home BCS= |Home Coach=[[Dennis Franchione]] |Home1=9 |Home2=6 |Home3=14 |Home4=0 |Home Total=29 |Type=Conference rivalry game |Stadium=[[Kyle Field]] |City=[[College Station, Texas|College Station]], [[Texas]] }} <!-- Note: The rankings and records in the Infobox NCAA football single game ABOVE are given coming INTO this specific game. -->
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2005 |Team=Texas Longhorns |Image=UT&Tmark.png |Conference=Big 12 Conference |Division=South |ShortConference=Big 12 |CoachRank=1 |APRank=1 |BCSRank=1 |Record=13-0 |ConfRecord=9-0 |HeadCoach=[[Mack Brown]] |OffCoach= [[Greg Davis (American football)|Greg Davis]] |DefCoach= [[Gene Chizik]] & [[Duane Akina]] |OScheme= [[Offensive philosophy (American football)#The Spread|Spread Option]] |DScheme= [[4-3]] |StadiumArena=[[Darrell K. Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium]] (85,123) |Champion=Big 12 Conference, BCS National Champions |Bowl=2006 Rose Bowl |BowlResult=41-38 }}
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2005 |Team=Texas A&M Aggies |Image= Texas A&M University aTm logo.svg |ImageSize= 152px |Conference=Big 12 Conference |Division=South |ShortConference=Big 12 |CoachRank= |APRank= |Record=5-6 |ConfRecord=3-5 |HeadCoach=[[Dennis Franchione]] |OffCoach=[[Les Koenning, Jr.]] |DefCoach=[[Carl Torbush]] |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kyle Field]] (82,600) |Champion= |BowlTourney= |BowlTourneyResult= }}
The '''2005 Texas vs. Texas A&M football game''', played November 25, 2005, was the 112th meeting between [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas at Austin]] and [[Texas A&M University]] in a [[college football]] game. Texas came into the game ranked number 2 in the nation while Texas A&M was unranked.
It was the eleventh game of the [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|2005 season]] and the final regular-season game for both teams. Texas had a 10-win, 0-loss record and Texas A&M was 5 and 5. For Texas, a win would make them sole winner of the Big 12 South division and they would go on to play in the [[Big 12 Conference Championship]]. With a loss, they still would play for the conference championship but it would have jeopardized their goal of ultimately playing in the [[NCAA Division I-A national football championship|BCS National Championship Game]]. The Aggies needed a win to have a winning record on the season and to be [[bowl eligible]].
The [[2005 Texas Longhorn football team]] (variously "Texas" or "UT" or the "Horns") was coached by head football coach [[Mack Brown]] and led on the field by [[quarterback]] [[Vince Young]]. The [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M Aggies]] (variously "Texas A&M" or "A&M" or the "Aggies") were coached by [[Dennis Franchione]]. [[Stephen McGee]] led the Aggies as quarterback due to an injury to starting-quarterback [[Reggie McNeal]].
The game drew a stadium crowd of 86,616 and the game was televised nationally on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. The contest was a back-and-forth affair which was ultimately won by Texas, 40â29. Although Texas won, it turned out to be the poorest performance of the season by the Longhorns, both [[Offense (sports)|offensively]] and [[Offense (sports)|defensively]]; the game also damaged the [[Heisman Trophy]] hopes of Vince Young. For Texas A&M, the loss capped a 5-6 losing season and made them ineligible for a post-season bowl.
==Lone Star Showdown== {{main|Lone Star Showdown}} This game marked the 112th meeting between Texas and the [[Texas A&M Aggies]] and the annual football game is part of a multi-sport rivalry called the [[Lone Star Showdown]]. It is the longest-running rivalry for both the Longhorns and the Aggies and it is also one of the ten most-played rivalries in college football.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.1122productions.com/rivalries/a.html | title=College Football Rivalries | accessdate=2007-03-31|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090215050109/http://www.1122productions.com/rivalries/a.html |archivedate = February 15, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Texas came into the 2005 contest with a 72â34â5 record,<ref name="All-Time Records vs. Opponents">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=298&change_well_id=2 | title=All Time Record vs. Opponents | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref> including victories in the last five meetings.<ref name="six in a row">{{cite news | url=http://www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/11/22/Sports/Chadvantage-2506576.shtml?norewrite200611220920&sourcedomain=www.thebatt.com | title=Can the Aggies snap their six-game losing streak against Texas? | author=Pederson, Eric and Ransom, Eric | publisher=The Battalion | date=22 November 2006 | accessdate=2006-11-23}}</ref><ref name="AP recap"/> During the week before the game, the Longhorns conducted their traditional [[Hex Rally]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/longhorns/entries/2005/11/17/texas_hex_rally_set_for_monday.html | title=Texas hex rally set for Monday | publisher=Austin American-Statesman | date=November 17, 2005 | accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref> As a result of a tragic accident in 1999, the Aggies could not host a school sponsored version of their traditional [[Aggie Bonfire|Bonfire]]<ref>{{cite news | url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2005/11/16/MailCall/Bonfire.Needs.Support.Of.Student.Body-1058980.shtml | title=Bonfire needs support of student body | publisher=The Battalion | date=November 16, 2005 | author=Dugan, Patrick | accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref> but an unofficial version called "Student Bonfire" was held.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.studentbonfire.com/pages/about.html | title=About student bonfire | publisher=Student Bonfire | accessdate=2007-03-31 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070315203742/http://www.studentbonfire.com/pages/about.html |archivedate = 2007-03-15}}</ref>
Since the series began in 1900<ref name="all time results">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1349&change_well_id=2 | title=All-Time Results | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | date=15 November 2006 | accessdate=2006-11-15}}</ref> it has traditionally played on [[Thanksgiving Day]] or Thanksgiving weekend. The 2005 game marked the twelfth straight game to be scheduled the day after Thanksgiving.<ref name="atm game notes">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/2006_atm_notes.pdf |format=PDF| title=Game Notes - Texas A&M | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2006-11-23}}</ref>
==Leading into the 2005 game== Like the Longhorns' [[2005 Texas Longhorn football team#Missouri|contest against Missouri]] earlier in the season, the Texas A&M game was touted as showcasing twoâof the best [[Quarterback#Dual-threat quarterbacks|dual-threat quarterbacks]] playing in college football.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nationalchamps.net/2005/sub/previews/texasam.htm | title=#18 Texas A&M | publisher=NationalChamps.net | accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref><ref name="Threat of Vince Young">{{cite news | url=http://www.kusports.com/news/football_archive/story/116076 | title=The threat of Vince Young - KU knows â QB burned Jayhawks last season| publisher=KUSports | date=November 11, 2005 | author=Wood, Ryan | accessdate=2007-03-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070928030639/http://www.kusports.com/news/football_archive/story/116076 |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=40&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1424&change_well_id=2 | title=Friendly rivalry | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | date=August 19, 2005 | accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/big12/2005-08-16-aggies-season_x.htm | title=Franchione, Texas A&M set for next big step| publisher=USA Today | date=August 16, 2005 | author=Weiberg, Steve | accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> However, Texas A&M's dual-threat quarterback [[Reggie McNeal]] missed the game due to an ankle injury; instead, [[freshman]] quarterback [[Stephen McGee]] made his first start.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/longhorns/entries/2005/11/25/injured_am_quarterback_reggie_mcneal_wont_play.html | title=Injured A&M quarterback Reggie McNeal wonât play | publisher=Austin American-Statesman | date=November 25, 2005 | accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref>
It was the eleventh game of the [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|2005 season]] and the final regular-season game for both teams. Texas came into the game with a 10âwin, 0âloss record and Texas A&M was 5 and 5. For Texas, a win would make them sole winner of the Big 12 South division and they would go on to play in the [[Big 12 Conference Championship]]. With a loss, they still would play for the conference championship but their goal of them playing in the [[NCAA Division I-A national football championship|BCS National Championship Game]] would be jeapordized.<ref name="AP recap"/><ref name="Longhorns stay perfect"/> The Aggies needed a win to have a winning record on the season and to be [[bowl eligible]]. The game was played at the Texas A&M campus in [[College Station]]. The apparent mismatch in abilities between the two teams, coupled with the injury to McNeal, led to a sober pre-game mood for the Aggies.<ref name="Texas eye's openned">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/Sports/Texas.Eyes.Opened.In.Win.Over.The.Aggies-1113934.shtml | title=Texas' eyes opened in win over the Aggies | publisher=The Daily Texan | author=Orchard, Phillip | date=November 28, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-26|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930201054/http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/Sports/Texas.Eyes.Opened.In.Win.Over.The.Aggies-1113934.shtml |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> {{see|2005 NCAA Division I-A football rankings|2005 Texas Longhorn football team#Rankings}}
==First quarter== [[File:Kyle-field-1.jpg|right|thumb|Texas at Texas A&M]] {{See also|American football rules|American football positions|American football strategy|Glossary of American football}} UT won the [[coin flipping|coin toss]] and decided to [[kickoff (American football)|kick off]]. The Aggies took a [[touchback]] and started on their own 20 [[Glossary of American football#Y|yard line]]. Stephen McGee kept the ball himself for an eight yard gain on [[first down]]; he followed this with a ten yard gain on [[Glossary of American football#S|second down]]. The next two plays were also [[rush (American football)|running plays]]: two yards by [[Jorvorskie Lane]] and ten yards by [[Courtney Lewis]], to bring the ball to mid-field. Lane rushed again for six yards followed by a ten yard run by Lewis. On 2nd and four on the UT 44 yard line McGee attempted his first [[forward pass|pass]] ([[Glossary of American football#I|intended]] for [[DeQwan Mobley]]) but it was [[incomplete pass|incomplete]]. Both teams were called with [[Glossary of American football#P|personal foul penalties]] on the play. McGee threw another pass and an A&M [[American football rules#Fouls and their penalties|penalty]] was declined by Texas to bring up [[Glossary of American football#F|fourth down]] fourth down. [[Justin Brantly]]'s [[Punt (football)|punt]] went into the [[end zone]] for a touchback.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
The Longhorns began their drive with a two yard rush by Vince Young. He followed this with a 24 yard pass to tight end [[David Thomas (American football)|David Thomas]]. [[Ramonce Taylor]] then lost two yards on a running play and Vince Young made five yards on 2nd and twelve. One 3rd and seven, Young's pass to [[Billy Pittman]] fell incomplete. This led to [[Richmond McGee]] punting the ball to the Texas A&M 13 where [[Todd Pegram]] made a fair catch. On A&M's second possession McGee rushed twice (-4 yards, +2 yards) then threw an [[interception]] to UT's [[Drew Kelson]]. Young's first down pass to Billy Pittman was incomplete. Ramonce Taylor rushed for five yards to the A&M 12 and a penalty against the Aggies moved the ball to the eight yard line. [[Henry Melton]] punched in the [[touchdown]] and the [[extra point]] by [[David Pino]] gave Texas a seven point lead.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
The Aggies were not able to gain a first down and after their punt the Longhorns had the ball around mid-field. They mounted a seven play, 48 yard drive culminating in a five yard Ramonce Taylor touchdown run. Texas A&M answered with a scoring drive of their own: 12 plays, 67 yards, and three points from a Todd Pegram [[field goal (football)|field goal]]. This made the score Texas 14, Texas A&M 3.
Texas got the ball on their own 35 and Vince Young immediately through a pass that was picked off my [[Melvin Bullitt]] near mid-field, with a return to the UT 35. Texas A&M ran a [[trick play]] by having [[running back]] Jorvorsky Lane throw the ball to Jason Carter for a touchdown.<ref name="AP recap"/><ref name="aTm-box"/> According to the [[Associated Press]], the touchdown "whipped the crowd of 86,617 into a frenzy as the Aggie fans waved their white [[Traditions of Texas A&M University#12th man towel|12th Man Towels]]."<ref name="AP recap"/> They tried to follow this by a trick [[two-point conversion]] but Todd Pegram's pass was intercepted by UT's [[Brian Robison]] to leave the score at UT 14, TAMU 9. Texas got the ball at their 33 and ran only one play for a slight loss before time expired in the first quarter.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
==Second quarter== Beginning the second quarter with 2nd and 13 at his own team's 30 yard line, Vince Young threw one incomplete pass to [[Quan Cosby]] and then a 21 yard [[Glossary of American football#C|completion]], also to Cosby. Billy Pittman ran for nine yards and this was followed by a six yard loss by Ramonce Taylor. On third and seven Vince Young was unable to connect with Limas Sweed and so Richmond McGee came in to punt again. Texas A&M got the ball on their 15 yard line and advanced the 85 yards in seven plays and just under four minutes of game clock. They scored on a [[Brandon Leone]] touchdown run but the attempt by Jorvorskie Lane at rushing for the two point conversion failed and the resulting score was Texas 14, Texas A&M 15.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
An [[Unsportsmanlike conduct]] penalty against Brandon Leone and a 21 yard return by Ramonce Taylor gave the Longhorns good field position at their own 46 yard line, but Jamaal Charles immediately gave the ball up to the Aggies on a [[fumble]]. The Texas defense sacked McGee on the next series and the Aggies were unable to gain sufficient yardage for a first down so they punted the ball away. This time, Texas moved the ball quickly; they advanced 77 yards in just seven plays and less than three minutes. Their touchdown and extra point made the score UT 21, A&M 15. The Aggies drove back to the UT 34 and attempted a field goal but it fell short of the [[goal posts]]. The Longhorns were able to run two plays (an incomplete pass and a sack of Vince Young) before time expired in the half.<ref name="aTm-box"/> The score at half time was Texas 21, Texas A&M 15.<ref name="Longhorns stay perfect">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/TopStories/Longhorns.Stay.Perfect-1113950.shtml | title=Longhorns stay perfect - Texas improves to 11-0 on the season despite an ugly win over Texas A&M Friday | publisher=The Daily Texan | author=Ransom, Eric | date=November 28, 2005 | accessdate=2007-06-19|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070928003514/http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/TopStories/Longhorns.Stay.Perfect-1113950.shtml |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="aTm-box"/>
==Third quarter== UT got the ball to start the second half; according to ''[[The Daily Texan]]'', the quarter started out "like a nightmare" for the Longhorns.<ref name="Longhorns stay perfect"/> On their third play, Vince Young was [[quarterback sack|sacked]] and fumbled the ball, which was recovered by A&M. Stephen McGee kept the ball himself for two straight rushing plays and a touchdown. The extra point gave the Aggies the lead again: 22â21.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
Young threw two short pass completions to Limas Sweed and Texas was able to reach midfield. Henry Melton was just inches short of converting a third-and-three situation and the team faced fourth down. Brown called a fake punt and the snap went to linebacker [[Rashad Bobino]]. Bobino rushed six yards straight up the middle to keep the drive alive, and a [[Glossary of American football#F|face mask penalty]] against the Aggies tacked on more yardage to put the ball at the A&M 23-yard line. Speaking of the fake punt, Brown said, "We prepared that each week. But we've been running the ball and moving the ball so well that we haven't used it [previously in the season]."<ref name="Longhorns stay perfect"/> On first down, Young threw a nine-yard completion to receiver Quan Cosby. This led to a Ramonce Taylor touchdown 10 plays, 80 yards, 4:21 minutes after the drive began.<ref name="aTm-box"/> After the extra point the Horns were leading 28-22.<ref name="Longhorns stay perfect"/><ref name="aTm-box"/>
Texas A&M was not able to get a first down so they attempted to punt; but [[Justin Brantley]]'s kick was blocked by [[Cedric Griffin]] and he ran it the eleven yards for a touchdown.<ref name="AP recap">{{cite news | url=http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200511250084 | title=(2) Texas 40, Texas A&M 29 | agency=Associated Press | author=Vertuno, Jim | date=November 25, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-26}}</ref><ref name="aTm-box"/> The extra point was [[Glossary of American football#N|no good]], so the score was Texas 34, Texas A&M 22. A&M came right back with an eight play drive to make it a five point game; the third quarter ended with the Longhorns on offense and the score at 34â29 in favor of the Longhorns.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
==Fourth quarter== Texas settled for a field goal to start the fourth quarter. This extended their lead to eight points. The Aggies mounted another long drive (9 plays, 67 yards, 05:13 in time of possession) and advanced to the UT 10 but McGee fumbled the ball over to Texas. Texas drove the ball to their 45 yard line but their drive stalled and they punted the ball. A&M's Carpenter fumbled and UT took over at the A&M 23. They were only able to advance to the 16 yard line and then they attempted a field goal; but Pino's kick was [[Glossary of American football#|wide right]] and the Aggies got the ball back on their 20. Their drive resulted in a punt back to Texas. The Horns moved down to the A&M 12 before again being stopped by the Aggie defense. Once again they sent in David Pino for a field goal and this time the kick was good, making the score Texas 40, Texas A&M 29 with 2:22 left in the game.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
The Aggies got the ball on their 23 and made it as far as the 30 before being pushed back to their 28. They [[Glossary of American football#T|turned the ball over on downs]]. Texas [[Glossary of American football#T|took a knee]] three times to end the game. The final score was Texas 40, Texas A&M 29.<ref name="aTm-box"/>
==Analysis== The game was the poorest performance of the season by the Longhorns, both offensively and defensively. On offense, Vince Young had only 162 yards of offense, his lowest output of the season.<ref name="aTm-box"/> The Associated Press remarked on the poor performance and said that Young, considered one of the nation's best quarterbacks and a [[Heisman trophy]] candidate coming into the game, was not even the best quarterback on the field that day.<ref name="AP recap"/><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/games/2005-11-25-texas-am_x.htm | title=Young held in check, but Texas checkmates Aggies | author=Vertuno, Jim | agency=Associated Press | date=November 25, 2005 | accessdate=2007-06-19}}</ref> ''The Daily Texan'' predicted that the game could hurt Young's chances for the Heisman, but they also quoted UT head coach [[Mack Brown]] as saying "Looking at the numbers from what [[Reggie Bush]] did last week and Vince did today, Reggie probably leads, but next week, Vince plays at noon, and Reggie at 3, so I think voters will wait and watch to see what happens."<ref name="Texas eye's openned"/>
UT running backs Henry Melton and Ramonce Taylor also came in for criticism.<ref name="Texas eye's openned"/><ref name="Texas focuses"/> Taylor was criticized for running backwards and sideways in an effort to gain yards, instead of moving ahead and breaking tackles. ''The Daily Texan'' observed "Five of Taylor's 15 carries resulted in a loss or no gain for a total of minus-17 yards. However, the other 10 carries totaled 119 yards for an average of 11.9 yards per positive running play. The sophomore didn't have a positive gain of fewer than 5 yards and accumulated three runs of 20 yards or longer." [[Greg Davis (American football)|Greg Davis]], UT's offensive coordinator, said ""Ramonce is a darter. The only time that really concerned me was a third-and-two situation. We talked to him on the sideline about a little bit more down and distance awareness."<ref name="Texas focuses">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/Sports/Texas.Focuses.On.Their.Goal-1113930.shtml | title=Texas focuses on their goal - Taylor uses speed, agility to break loose from opponents | publisher=The Daily Texan | author=Veyhl, Jake | date=November 28, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-26|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930222204/http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/11/28/Sports/Texas.Focuses.On.Their.Goal-1113930.shtml |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Melton was criticized for "tiptoeing indecisively" and letting himself get tackled near the [[line of scrimmage]].<ref name="Texas eye's openned"/>
On defense, the Longhorns held A&M to only 118 yards passing but gave up 277 yards rushing, which was the highest total given up by the Longhorns during the season. Despite the poor outing, Texas won by a final score of 40â29 to finish the regular season undefeated.<ref name="aTm-box">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/000_stats/05/ut11.htm | title=Texas vs Texas A&M (November 25, 2005) | work=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2006-07-30}}</ref> The eleven point win was their second smallest margin of victory of the regular season and they lost points in all three major polls but still remained solidly in second place nationally.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/longhorns/entries/2005/11/27/horns_lose_votes_in_all_three_polls.html | title=Horns lose votes in all three polls | publisher=Austin American-Statesman | author=Bridges, John | date=November 27, 2005 | accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref> [[Gene Chizik]], UT's [[defensive coordinator]], said "This really is an eye-opening experience. Obviously, we've got to get better. But I'll tell you what, we're all going to drive home 11-0."<ref name="Longhorns stay perfect"/>
The game's attendance was 86,616,<ref name="aTm-box"/> 4,016 more people than the official capacity of Kyle Field.<ref name="KF_Attendance">{{cite web | url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/facilities.php?FID=7 | title=Kyle Field | work=Official Website of Texas A&M Athletics | accessdate=2006-09-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060823182049/http://www.aggieathletics.com/facilities.php?FID=7 |archivedate = 2006-08-23}}</ref>
==After the game==
Texas eventually finished the [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|season of 2005-2006]] as the only undefeated team, winning both the [[Big 12 Conference]] championship<ref name="Texas overpowers">{{cite news | title=Texas Overpowers Colorado To Win Big 12 football Championship | url=http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/120305aaa.html | publisher=Big 12 Conference | date=December 3, 2005 | accessdate=2006-12-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109193349/http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/120305aaa.html |archivedate = 2006-11-09}}</ref> and the [[NCAA Division I-A national football championship|National Championship]].<ref name="Texas beats USC">{{cite news | url=http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/010506aaa.html | title=Texas Wins National Championship, Beats USC 41-38 - Vince Young scrambles for an 8-yard touchdown on fourth down with 19 seconds left to take lead. | publisher=Big 12 Conference | date=January 4, 2006 | accessdate=2006-12-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061106174905/http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/010506aaa.html |archivedate = 2006-11-06}}</ref>
The Longhorns' penultimate victory of the season, in the [[Big 12 Football Championship Game|Big 12 Championship Game]], featured the biggest margin of victory in the history of that contest. Their ultimate victory in the 2006 [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] against the [[University of Southern California]] [[2005 USC Trojans football team|Trojans]] for the national championship, as well as their overall season, have both been cited as standing among the greatest performances in college football history by publications such as ''[[College Football News]]'',<ref name="10 greatest">{{cite news | url=http://cfn.scout.com/2/564658.html | title=Tuesday Question - Ten Greatest Bowl Games | date=September 5, 2006 | publisher=College Football News | author=Cirminiello, Richard and Harris, John | accessdate=2006-12-13}}</ref><ref name="CFB best ever">{{cite news | author=Fiutak, Pete | url=http://www.collegefootballnews.com/2006/TQ/Rose_Best.htm | title=Was the 2006 Rose Bowl the best college football game ever? | publisher=College Football News | date=10 January 2006 | accessdate=2006-10-20 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060616201851/http://www.collegefootballnews.com/2006/TQ/Rose_Best.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-16}}</ref><ref name="CCFN">{{cite news | author=Fiutak, Pete | url=http://www.collegefootballnews.com/Almanac/CFN_Formula/CFN_FormulaAllTime.htm |title=Formula and Calculations for All-Time Greatest Football Teams | publisher=College Football News | accessdate=2006-06-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060614161713/http://www.collegefootballnews.com/Almanac/CFN_Formula/CFN_FormulaAllTime.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-14}}</ref> the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'',<ref name="grand">{{cite news | url=http://www.ajc.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/ajc/sportscolumns/entries/2006/01/06/rose_bowl_a_gra.html | title=BCS enjoys 'grand cresendo' | publisher=Atlanta Journal-Constitution | author=Furman Bisher | date=2006-01-06 | accessdate=2006-12-12}}</ref> ''Scout.com'',<ref name="Scouts best">{{cite news | url=http://louisianastate.scout.com/2/596414.html | title=Is the bloom off the Rose? | author=Defresne, Chris | publisher=Scouts.com | date=December 1, 2006 | accessdate=2006-12-13}}</ref> and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.<ref name="YoungNite">{{cite news | author=Murphy, Austin | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/preview/siexclusive/2006/pr/subs/siexclusive/01/05/cf.bcs0109/ | title=The Night is Young's | publisher=Sports Illustrated | date=5 January 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-30}}</ref> The Longhorns and the Trojans were together awarded the 2006 [[ESPY Award]] by [[ESPN]] for the "Best Game" in any sport.<ref name="TexasTrifecta">Fisher, Gerren LaQuint{{Cite news | url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2006/07/14/Sports/Texas.Snags.Espy.Trifecta-2131713.shtml?norewrite200607252146&sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com | title=Texas snags ESPY trifecta - 2006 Rose Bowl voted Best Game of the year, Vince gets Best Championship Performance | publisher=The Daily Texan | date=14 July 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-25 | author=Fisher, Gerren LaQuint|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070928003440/http://www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2006/07/14/Sports/Texas.Snags.Espy.Trifecta-2131713.shtml?norewrite200607252146&sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}} </ref> The Longhorns finished the season as the only unbeaten team, with 13 wins and zero losses overall.<ref name="Win/Loss>College football team records are conventionally expressed in number of wins/losses. 13-0 means 13 wins and zero losses.</ref><ref name="Big12_standings">{{cite web | url = http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/06_records_3_big12.pdf | format = PDF | title=All Time Big-12 Standings | work = MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-06-26}}</ref>
The season gave Texas its second Big 12 football championship<ref name="Big12_standings"/> (27 conference championships total, including 25 in the [[Southwest Conference]]),<ref name="SWC_standings">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/06_records_3_swc.pdf | format = PDF | title=All Time SWC Standings | work=MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-06-26}}</ref> and fourth consensus national championship in football.<ref name="NCAA_Championship_list">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncaa.org/champadmin/ia_football_past_champs.html | title=Past Division I-A Football National Champions | work=NCAA.org | accessdate=2006-06-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060613014918/http://www.ncaa.org/champadmin/ia_football_past_champs.html |archivedate = 2006-06-13}}</ref> It was the ninth [[List of undefeated Division I-A football teams|perfect season]] in the history of Longhorn football.<ref name="All time results">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1349&change_well_id=2 | title=University of Texas - all time records | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-12-05}}</ref>
UT set numerous school and [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] records, including most points scored in a season (652). After the season ended, six Longhorns from this championship team were selected by [[National Football League|professional football teams]] in the [[2006 NFL Draft]].<ref name="NFL-draft">{{cite web | url=http://nfl.com/draft/drafttracker/school/TX | title=Draft Tracker - Texas | work=NFL.com - Official website of the NFL | date=30 April 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060708171702/http://www.nfl.com/draft/drafttracker/school/TX |archivedate = 2006-07-08}}</ref>
With the loss, the Aggies ended up with a losing record for the regular season and consequently they were not [[bowl eligible]]. That meant that this game concluded the season for Texas A&M. However, their close defeat in 2005 was followed by an [[upset]] victory in 2006 as the [[2006 Texas A&M Aggies football team|2006 Aggies]] defeated the [[2006 Texas Longhorn football team|2006 Longhorns]] to snap a six-game losing streak.<ref name="Texas a&m 2006 game notes">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=&url_article_id=2643&change_well_id=2 | title=Texas A&M Game notes | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | date=24 November 2006 | accessdate=2006-11-25}}</ref><ref name="snaps six streak">{{cite news | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=263280251 | title=Texas A&M runs down Texas to snap 6-game series skid | agency=Associated Press | date=24 November 2006 | accessdate=2006-11-25}}</ref>
